awd_titl_txt: River Region Master Teaching Fellowships in Environmental Sustainability
awd_abstract_narration:
To help meet the need for highly qualified STEM teachers in Southern Illinois and surrounding areas, Southern Illinois University Carbondale (SIUC) will implement a Track 3 Robert Noyce Master Teaching Fellowship project.  The project focuses on environmental sustainability, with the aims of addressing local environmental problems and modernizing the STEM curricula, thereby training secondary school students for college success and living-wage jobs. To accomplish the project goals, SIUC is partnering with the Carbondale Science Center and high-need schools and school districts in the region. Participating schools or school districts include Belleville Township High School West, Cairo Jr./Sr. High School, Carruthers School, Norris City-Omaha-Enfield High School, Grayville Community Unit School District 1, Trico Community Unit School District 176, and Steeleville Community Unit School District 138.  The project will select fifteen middle and high school teachers with master's degrees to serve as Master Teaching Fellows.  Selection criteria include performance as educators, content knowledge, and commitment to enhancing STEM teaching practice through innovative and effective pedagogy. These Master Teaching Fellows will engage in summer research experiences and professional development throughout the five-year project. 

The goal of the project is to improve educational practices of STEM teacher leaders through engaging activities, targeted mentoring, and partnership with a local community Science Center. Participants will engage in a five-year program that integrates four core experiences throughout: content enhancement, research experiences, pedagogy, and leadership. Through teacher professional development, science literacy enhancement, and authentic research experiences, Master Teaching Fellows will lead their schools and districts to improve STEM education for thousands of underserved students in the rural River Region. Engagement of Master Teaching Fellows in collaborative efforts to enhance displays and events at the Science Center of Carbondale has the potential to reach learners in an informal setting and enhance science literacy in the community. Leadership development will be systematically incorporated into each year of the program through coursework, through pre-service and novice teacher mentoring, and through school reform activities. Program elements will follow a progression of topics through general sustainability concepts, toxicology/waste management, biodiversity, global environmental change, and energy. Coursework and authentic research experiences follow these topics and will culminate in a graduate Certificate in Sustainability designed specifically for teachers. will take science content courses prior to engaging in five consecutive Summer Research Institutes that immerse them for three weeks in inquiry-based and research activities mentored by SIUC researchers and science education experts. Activities will be designed to impart problem-solving, inquiry and critical thinking skills to students. During Summer Research Institutes, Master Teaching Fellows will also develop sustainability plans specific to their schools, such as reduction of pesticide loading and conservation of local energy usage. Master Teaching Fellows will develop and implement classroom activities based upon their coursework and research experiences. These activities will be NGSS-aligned, assessed through Action Research, and fine-tuned to maximize student learning. Student outcomes will be assessed through pre- and post-tests, established attitude and STEM assessment instruments, and high-quality tests developed by Illinois that are NGSS-aligned. Master Teaching Fellows will be guided via leadership workshops, coursework, and mentoring to increase professional knowledge, skills, and dispositions necessary to lead and bring about positive change in STEM education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
This Master Teaching Fellowship program was a partnership among Southern Illinois University Carbondale (SIUC) and school districts in the high needs region at the confluence of the Mississippi, Ohio and Wabash Rivers (River Region) that includes three states. Faculty participants included experienced members from the College of Education and the College of Science, including three recognized University Distinguished Scholars. Through extensive recruitment efforts from all high-need middle and high schools within a 125-mile radius of Carbondale, we identified 115 individual teachers from high need schools and selected fifteen Master Teaching Fellows (MTFs) to participate for five years in the program.

Due to involvement in the Noyce program, participating teachers acknowledged the value of the training they received. They identified benefits of the program that led to productive collaborations and enhanced credibility among peers and administrators. Noyce opened new opportunities that increased their professional networks, enriched their practice, and contributed to gained confidence as they progressively viewed themselves as leaders who could impact progress and support their peers.

Intellectual Merit: All experiences during the five-year program were grounded in evidence-based, effective practice. MTFs engaged in four core training experiences: science content, scientific research, pedagogy, and leadership. The themes of successive years were centered around environmental sustainability as follows: year 1, fundamentals of sustainability; year 2, toxicology and sustainable agriculture; year 3, biodiversity; year 4, climate change; and year 5, photovoltaic energy. Each year, MTFs and invited teachers engaged in a 3-week Summer Research Immersion (SRI) during which they gained content knowledge, developed classroom activities and conducted a research project related to the yearly theme. Successive years were designed to build on research skills as teachers became proficient in more challenging aspects of the scientific process. During the academic year, MTFs took classes in leadership and pedagogy that focused on school improvement, curriculum and assessment, and action research. They also integrated what they learned during the SRI into their curricula. MTFs progressively assumed more leadership roles in the schools and districts, including curriculum development, peer mentoring, leading professional development sessions, serving on committees, implementing new programs, and engaging parents and community members in educational endeavors. All of the MTFs presented the results of their efforts at regional, state or national meetings. During the course of the project, faculty, staff and participants completed 81 total products of which 67 were conference posters or presentations, 12 were peer-reviewed journal publications and 2 were websites.

Broader Impacts: The activities in our program provided meaningful experiences that enable MTFs and regional teachers to become highly effective STEM educators and leaders in the high need, impoverished region around Southern Illinois (including 8 of the 10 counties with the highest poverty levels in Illinois). MTFs engaged fully in the scientific process and gained knowledge of effective pedagogy and science content related to environmental sustainability. Teachers designed lessons and activities that addressed local environmental problems, thereby engaging thousands of students in rural communities in innovative and relevant hands-on, inquiry and place-based STEM activities. The program provided teaching resources and shared equipment to MTFs and participating teachers such as microscopes and an EMRiver Stream table for modeling river processes. Participant teachers enhanced leadership skills through developing an annual Family Eco Festival that engages the community members and partner organizations in relevant STEM learning designed to increase science literacy. To sustain efforts and broaden impacts, teachers established and raised funds for a non-profit through which regional teachers are supported in implementing experiential learning activities in their classroom and with the public.
